Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Heat exchanger coating retrofit pre-treatment feasibility study
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will address the challenge of retrofit cleaning and pretreatment of steam condenser tubes prior to the deposition of a performance-enhancing coating. By eliminating the buildup of the insulating film of liquid that normally forms on condenser surfaces, the coating increases the vapor-side heat transfer coefficient by more than a factor of seven, allowing the condenser to pull more steam through the turbine. The successful application of this coating would enable significant increases in cycle efficiencies of in the installed base of steam power plants that generate the vast majority of national electricity, leading to substantial reductions in fuel costs, greenhouse gas emissions, and thermal pollution. This coating technology can be extended to other systems including desalination and heating, ventilating, air conditioning, and refrigeration (HVAC/R), which also rely on condensers to operate efficiently.

The intellectual merit of this project comprises the acquisition of systematic knowledge of metal-oxide fouling and deposits in industrial environments, and the development of scalable pretreatment strategies to bridge the gap between laboratory and field-deployed coating depositions. Because this application of hydrophobic coatings has not been achieved at a commercial scale, there currently exists little to no systematic research on the condition of heat exchanger surfaces. The results of this study will be applicable to industrial coatings on industrial equipment beyond just heat exchangers, including distillation columns and moisture separators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DropWise Technologies Corp. is developing an advanced heat exchanger coating technology to eliminate the buildup of condensate on heat exchanger surfaces, boosting thermal performance to maximize efficiency in steam power cycles. In addition to fuel savings, the efficiency improvement provided by the coating assists compliance with current and upcoming emissions and wastewater regulations. The magnitude of efficiency enhancement from a relatively low-cost infrastructure upgrade is unprecedented; there are no similar plant efficiency upgrades available.

Given the small number of new builds relative to installed power plant capacity, dropwise coatings must be able to be applied as a retrofit to existing equipment to have a transformational impact on the energy sector. One option is to pre-coat tubes and then retube the condenser with coated tubes. However, as power plant steam condensers can have 10,000-20,000 tubes, this retubing process can take 2 to 5 weeks. Additionally, plants commonly go more than 40 years without retubing. The costs of the tubes and the downtime make this approach very uneconomical. Thus, it is necessary to apply the coatings in-situ to existing condensers.

Prior to the work performed during the SBIR Phase I grant, DropWise had published heat transfer and durability results of coatings deposited using initiated Chemical Vapor Deposition (iCVD) in Advanced Materials (Paxson, et al, Advanced Materials, 2013). These films demonstrated a 700% increase in steam condensation heat transfer versus an uncoated surface. However, the iCVD process used in this work required hot filaments to be put in close proximity to the surface to be coated. These filaments impose a difficulty in real world applications, particularly for power plant condensers where access is restricted, and so impede the commercialization of the coating overall.

Since October 2015, the SBIR Phase I project has been focused on scaling DropWise’s original coating technology to develop a process capable of depositing nanometer scale coatings on industrial heat exchangers. DropWise Technologies Corp made substantial technical progress during the course of the Phase I work towards this goal. A new version of initiated chemical vapor deposition was created, where energy requirements from traditional filaments have been replaced by a combination of substrate heating and other process conditions. Throughout the Phase I work, multiple iterations of the process were created and improved upon to explore the parameters controlling deposition rate such as temperatures and the stoichiometry of the reactants. The substrate temperature in particular requires optimization of the tradeoff between increasing reaction rate with higher temperature and decreased surface concentration of reactants at too high of substrate temperatures due to desorption. The optimization studies ultimately resulted in the development of an attachable system that uses a nitrogen carrier gas to deliver reactants to a chamber heated to a strategic temperature to generate a coating. The efficacy of this process was demonstrated on a miniature single tube condenser, which successfully modified the tube with a hydrophobic coating.

Our newly-developed process is capable of applying vapor deposited coatings at atmospheric pressure, eliminating one of the major technical challenges of commercializing the technology. The process also has fairly mild heating requirements and has been shown to produce coatings with deposition rates >1 nm/hr using temperatures below 125 °C. Additionally, the new process has completely eliminated the need for filaments making the process feasible for coating large complex substrates such as heat exchangers.

In conclusion, we successfully completed the objective of this Phase I grant to develop a process that could be more easily scaled up for retrofitting existing power generation steam condensers. We demonstrated deposition rates > 1nm/hr of polymer films without the need for heating filaments close to the substrate. This involved creating a new deposition process that pushed the bounds of the original technology and brings it significantly closer to commercialization. Deployment of the DropWise technology will ultimately greatly reduce emissions of steam power plants and other industrial processes.
